Kural_Info.Tamil_Text: பிறர்க்கின்னா முற்பகல் செய்யின் தமக்குஇன்னாபிற்பகல் தாமே வரும்.
Kural_Info.English_Meaning: If a man inflict sorrow upon others in the morning, it will come upon him unsought in the very evening.

Layered_Composition.Foreground: A split composition showing the same landscape at two different times of day.
Layered_Composition.Midground: On the left, in the morning ('முற்பகல்'), a person is shown inflicting harm or sorrow ('இன்னா') upon another. This act sends a dark, boomerang-like shadow into the sky.
Layered_Composition.Background: On the right, in the evening of the same day ('பிற்பகல்'), the person is shown trying to relax. The dark shadow-boomerang they launched in the morning is now seen returning on its own ('தாமே வரும்') and striking them, causing them to suffer the same sorrow they inflicted.

Art_Direction.Subject_and_Action: A direct and swift karmic law: the harm you do to others in the morning will return to you, of its own accord, by the evening.
Art_Direction.Symbolic_Motifs: The karmic boomerang is the central, simple, and powerful metaphor. The speed of the return—within a single day—is a key element to emphasize. The sorrow returns 'by itself', showing the automatic, impersonal nature of this law.
Art_Direction.Lighting_and_Color: The morning scene is in the clear, bright light of day. The evening scene is in the warm, long shadows of sunset, but the returning shadow-boomerang is a stark, cold black, bringing a sudden chill to the evening.

Technical_Cues.Camera: A diptych or a shot with a time-lapse effect that shows the entire cause-and-effect cycle within a single day.
Technical_Cues.Resolution: 8K, ultra-realistic, with a clear and powerful visual for the returning karmic boomerang.
Technical_Cues.Lighting: A clear transition from morning to evening light.
